text: All persons having business before the Honorable Chief Judge and Associate Judges now presiding over the District of Columbia Court of Appeals, draw near and give your attention. God save the United States and this Honorable Court. This Honorable Court is now in session. Please come to order. All right.
speaker: courtroomclerk

text: Thank you. Good morning again, everyone.  Welcome to the District of Columbia Court of Appeals Virtual Oral Arguments. And we'll begin with our first case today, Charmante Walker versus United States. Are you ready to proceed?
speaker: judgeblackburn

text: Yes, Your Honor. Good morning, Monica Milton on behalf of Mr. Charmante Walker, the appellant in this case. I would like to reserve two minutes for rebuttal. Okay. Judge, Your Honors, counsel, may it please the court.  Mr. Walker asked this court to reverse his convictions because Strickland and Brady violations unconstitutionally hampered his ability to prove his innocent or amount any defense. The Sixth Amendment to the United States Constitution guarantees every criminal defendant adequate and effective representation. The only defense Mr. Walker had against the ample power of the United States government would have been effective trial counsel.  Strickland versus Washington directs courts to analyze this under two prongs to determine whether counsel's assistance was ineffective. And that's whether the performance was sufficient. And Mr. Walker must show that that deficient performance prejudice the defense. With respect to performance, he has the burden to show that counsel's representation fell below objective and standard of reasonableness.  Mr. Attorney Jeffrey Lewis failed to make proper pre trial investigations failed to interview exculpatory witnesses and failed to present any evidence for the defense in that constitutes ineffective assistance of counsel.  The record indicates that Mr. Walker first alerted the court to Jeffrey Lewis's deficient performance three months before trial. And he stated that his attorney was not investigating. He was not filing pre-trial motions. And Mr. Walker was fearful that his attorney was not adequately prepared. And that bore out because Mr. Lewis did not present a defense for Mr. Walker.
speaker: monicamilton

text: Counsel, didn't the trial court check in with him subsequent to that and say, have your concerns been resolved and addressed? And your client said, yes, I'm OK now, and I'm ready to go.
speaker: judgeeasterly

text: Yes. Mr. Walker stated the reason that he said he was OK is because he knew that Judge Motley was not going to give him a new attorney. So he essentially gave up.  But prior to trial, Mr. Lewis was giving such inadequate pre-trial investigation that Judge Motley appointed co-counsel to help him. With respect... Ms.
speaker: monicamilton

text: Walker, just to follow up on that, when the court did hold the 23-110 ineffective assistance of counsel hearing,  There was extensive testimony and questioning back and forth and a number of inconsistencies where Mr. Walker claimed that he told his counsel about particular witnesses. And as the trial judge found, in some instances, that information wasn't shared prior to trial or in a timely way. And so the trial judge made a number of credibility findings based on  the testimony of counsel regarding the steps counsel did take during the investigation. How do you view our role in reversing some of those credibility findings where there was such extensive testimony and pretty detailed findings made by the trial court that trial counsel did investigate, did make some strategic decisions, and didn't have all of the information that the  Mr. Walker claimed that he had?
speaker: judgeblackburn

text: So with respect to the strategic decisions, at least one time during the 23-110 hearing, Attorney Lewis admitted that there was not a strategic basis for not investigating evidence to rebut the government's case. And secondly, attorney- Which evidence in particular?
speaker: monicamilton

text: Because there was a lot of evidence that would have  according to the trial judge been cumulative or not cogent in the trial judge's findings and view.
speaker: judgeblackburn

text: So at least two witnesses, one witness that attorney admitted that Chamonte Walker told him to investigate was someone that he identified in one of the government's videos. He said that he would have liked to interview and this individual's name was Jermaine. So attorney Lewis does admit that Mr. Walker was giving him lots of witnesses  And it seems to be the case that there was a pattern in practice. Mr. Lewis would dismiss them before even interviewing them. Now, the investigator is another story because we don't know he's passed away before the hearing what efforts he made. But Attorney Lewis at least stated that part of the reason the investigator wasn't meeting with witnesses was because of his own direction, stating that these things weren't relevant. Now,  Mr. Lewis was at least in possession of a Brady disclosure that indicated there was an eyewitness who said he heard and saw an argument between Mr. Carraway and the decedent before the shooting. And both Mr. Harn, the co-counsel appointed, or rather relatedly, but appointed before two weeks before trial, stated that they would have liked to have interviewed this person. And neither one of them did so.  This is a disinterested eyewitness who states that he heard an argument which was contrary to the government's proposition that there was a premeditated agreement before the shooting that they would all... The trial judge noted that at the time of the hearings, this witness, Mr. Thompson, could not be located.
speaker: monicamilton

text: Does the record say anything about whether he could be located pre-trial? I know that the investigator died, and I don't know at what point he died, but does the record say definitively one way or the other whether any efforts were made to find Mr. Thompson or whether he could have been found? I realize that his particular identity was not disclosed until later.  But does the record say anything about whether or not there were efforts to actually find him?
speaker: judgethompson

text: There was no indication that the Defense Council ever asked for the identity of this witness. I think at least during the 23-110 motion, both Attorney Hahn and Attorney Lewis said, we would have liked to speak to this person. We believe we asked for the identity, but the government never gave it to us.  So I think that in this instance, this court's presented with sort of the intersection of Brady and Strickland as to whether or not there was an affirmative duty for the government to have disclosed this information. But counsel, I mean, let's accept that that's deficient performance, right?
speaker: monicamilton

text: I mean, the government identifies this statement, I think, correctly by this witness, this observer.  as possibly favorable information, right? And the pretrial obligation to disclose is broader, right? They're supposed to disclose anything that's arguably favorable. So this is arguably favorable.  And they turn it over to defense counsel and defense counsel doesn't follow up doesn't ask for the name doesn't do anything with it fine it's deficient that now we're in the post conviction proceedings and looking retrospectively and we're trying to discern the prejudice the harm from this. And the fact of the matter is this account from this person in a window looking down on the scene.  doesn't match up with the video tape evidence, doesn't match up with the autopsy report, right? This person is saying that it's the face-to-face argument and the man is shot from the front. All evidence is that the decedent's shot from the back. So as far as sort of harm now, how can we say that this justifies a new trial or reversal relief for your client?
speaker: judgeeasterly

text: So I just want to challenge the notion that the shooting had to happen from the front. Just because there is an argument facing each other doesn't mean that the decedent didn't turn around if he observed a gun, that he could have turned around. He could have moved, maybe seeing the gun. So I don't think that there's evidence that  Just because there was an argument that was face to face, it means that that necessarily means he was shot face to face, he could have turned around to flee if he exerted a gun, he could have been.  alerted to that and turning around. So I don't think that that's inconsistent with the idea that they were in an argument, but it does go to the issue as to whether or not this was premeditated. And although the government asserts that there was an ample amount of evidence, I'm sure the court was able to view the video. The video really, there's no sound.  The video doesn't really indicate anything in terms of the context of this shooting, other than I don't think that that's an issue with that issue is whether or not there was an argument, whether or not that precipitated the shooting or whether there was before the shooting, there was an agreement because this Mr. Walker is convicted under an 80 and abetted abetting theory.  And although the trial judge said that there was ample amount of evidence, there's ample amount of evidence that Mr. Carraway shot Mr. Hendy, and we all agree with that. But we don't agree with whether or not there was an agreement beforehand. We don't have any disinterested witnesses testifying. Mr. Lewis does not want to examine Janetta Sapp, who's the property manager who claims to have identified Mr. Walker on this video.  makes no effort to cross-examine despite the graininess and lack of sound in the video. But didn't your client actually acknowledge that that was him on the video, that he was shown on the video?
speaker: monicamilton

text: I mean, there's a lot of Monday morning quarterbacking going on here. And we need to consider what the lawyers knew at the time they were making decisions. And they had both an acknowledgment by your client that he was shown on the video and a statement to police that he was shown on the video.  And there were several other witnesses, accounts about the so-called argument conflicted with what Mr. Thompson apparently said. So given all that, can you really make the case for prejudice here?  There's also the point, by the way, that any effort to undermine the video and the like would have just led to the government's effort to use Mr. Carraway in the rebuttal case, which would have been extremely damaging to your client.
speaker: judgethompson

text: Thank you for your question. With respect to the video, at the 23-110 hearing, Mr. Attorney Lewis does not say that this is the video that my client identified himself in. There were several videos and he admitted there was no dispute that he was near, he was on the scene, so to speak. So that's not disputed. It's just a matter of whether or not that this argument happened and the attorney says,  That went against what we knew to be the case, but that's the point. The only thing they had to go on was the government's proper and theory. So if there was an inconsistent eyewitness who could testify to something that was in conflict with the government's case, then it's constitutionally ineffective for one, that he did not go and try to seek out that witness. And secondly, that he would not have presented this disinterested witnesses testimony.  Despite the fact that the trial court believed that this was a strong case, it was a strong case to the extent that they were able to prove Mr. Carraway shot Mr. Hendy. The agreement was not a strong case. They had his ex-girlfriend testifying who benefited through government resources for relocation money. There was really no one that the government presented  that had personal knowledge of this case, that was stronger than this interested witness who witnessed, he's the only one that witnessed the shooting with his own eyes and heard and was able to identify.
speaker: monicamilton

text: Ms. Milton, I didn't want to interrupt you. You did reserve two minutes for rebuttal. And I don't know if either of my colleagues have any more questions or did you want to reserve the rest of your time for rebuttal?
speaker: judgeblackburn

text: I'll reserve the rest for rebuttal, thank you.
speaker: monicamilton

text: All right, thank you, Ms. Milton.  Mr. Han.
speaker: judgeblackburn

text: Thank you, Your Honor, and may it please the court, Brian Han for Appelli, the United States. I want to start with witnesses Hall, Brown, and Alondra Smith. And I think that Judge Motley's findings that  they never contacted Attorney Lewis and that appellant never told Attorney Lewis about those witnesses was not clearly erroneous. It's based on testimony from Attorney Lewis. It's based on inconsistencies and problems with the testimony of those witnesses and appellant himself. And so that finding is not clearly erroneous. And as- I think that's right.
speaker: bryanhan

text: Go to Mr. Thompson, the witness that was not investigated.  What do you have to say about that?
speaker: judgethompson

text: So I think there's a few things, Your Honor. I think, first of all, we're looking at this through the lens of an effective assistance of counsel in terms of Appellant 23-110 claim, whether or not they were deficient in not investigating this witness. And as the Supreme Court in Strickland has recognized, as this court in Kosio has recognized, an attorney's investigation is rightly guided by what their client tells them, or what his or her client tells them.  And what do you, what does the attorney listen to that right, I mean, the attorney is representing the client, because the client.
speaker: bryanhan

text: doesn't have the skills that the attorney has, right? I mean, the client has the Sixth Amendment right to counsel. That's got to mean something. So the client can't be driving all the decisions. And in fact, we say there are just a few decisions that are reserved to the client. Do they want to plead? Do they want to testify?  But as far as strategy, trial strategies, for sure, the lawyer is supposed to talk to the client and get the information that he can from the client. But he's supposed to do his job independent of the client, because clients come to the table with all sorts of capabilities, right? So I don't find that argument to be sort of dispositive here. Why else should we not be troubled about Mr. Thompson?
speaker: judgeeasterly

text: So I think that you're right, your honor, and that the attorney is supposed to use their own judgment when investigating the case. But I think that the argument is not that the client guides the investigation. It's that the information that the client has informs what the investigation is. And again, there's no  I mean appellant, you know, says he's there. There's no allegation that appellant is actually the gunman. Everyone agrees that it's Miko Caraway and appellant identifies himself on surveillance video of the scene. And so he's clearly there and  The testimony from Attorney Lewis is that at two points in the hearing is that, you know, appellant never gives us the names of anyone who can account for his movements on the scene, except for Corey Yates. And of course, you know, they can't call Corey Yates as a witness, or at least there are issues with that. And so I think that- When you say issues with that, are you talking, what issues are you referring to?
speaker: bryanhan

text: The fact that some- The fact that- He might've invoked the,  his Fifth Amendment rights or that they were having difficulty locating?
speaker: judgeblackburn

text: No, Corey Yates is the co-defendant, so I think it's the Fifth Amendment rights is the fact that they're both charged with the same crime in the case. I think that's the difficulty there. And  And going back to your question, Judge Eastley, I think that in terms of what investigation would be fruitful in this case to Attorney Lewis at the time that he has this case, he's got all this information that there was no face-to-face argument.  that the witness Fred Thompson describes. But wait a second, I mean, the government is making a Brady disclosure, right?
speaker: bryanhan

text: That in and of itself is notable and worth examining carefully. And the government says, you know, there is an eyewitness who says X.  that is sort of new information. Why wouldn't you want to know who this person is, talk to this person, and figure out if there are any other people who are with this person who can corroborate their account, what their vantage point was? Why wouldn't you want to investigate that need when the government is handing it to you and saying, we think this is possible Brady information? That seems like a significant oversight to me.
speaker: judgeeasterly

text: I think, Your Honor, that based on everything else they know about the case, I think it's reasonable for them not to have investigated that witness because the witness is so clearly incorrect in the description of what happened.  But I think that even if this court disagrees, if this court thinks they should have talked to them, sorry, that the attorney should have talked to Fred Thompson, I think that, again, as Judge Isholy, you yourself noted, in this posture when we're post-trial, when we're talking about Appellant's 23-110 motion,  as Judge Motley found, there's very little that this could have done to affect the outcome of the case. And again, that's because- What about Ms.
speaker: bryanhan

text: Milton's response to me, which is actually this did matter a lot because if this was a fight,  And if there's a face-to-face encounter and he then turns away and is shot in the back, if the shooting is attributable to a spur-of-the-moment flash of anger as opposed to a premeditated crime, that is definitely beneficial and possibly material to Mr. Walker.
speaker: judgeeasterly

text: I think that assumes, Your Honor, that this face-to-face argument would have been found, that the testimony about this face-to-face argument would have been found credible by the jury. And I think that Judge Motley finds that it's not credible because of this autopsy evidence, because of the video evidence. Again, there's not enough time, at least, tracking the movements of all the key players to the video for there to be this face-to-face argument.  And we also know that- Mr. Hahn, I'm sorry.
speaker: bryanhan

text: Was Judge Motley clearly confronted with the argument that Ms. Milton makes today? She says we presume that it was face-to-face and that that presumption is really not well-founded. Judge Motley made findings based on the autopsy. But was the specific argument made to him that this could have been a spur-of-the-moment, spin-around fight that maybe didn't take place face-to-face?
speaker: judgeblackburn

text: I don't think that the argument was made that this was a spur of the moment argument that this was not faced. I'm not sure I understand the question, Your Honor. Ms. Milton just posited to us when she was responding to some of our questions that we presumed and assumed.
speaker: bryanhan

text: And she challenged that assumption that this was face to face. And she posited that it could have been other circumstances. And I'm wondering if that  argument was clearly made to the trial judge when he made the findings that it was a face-to-face argument?
speaker: judgeblackburn

text: I don't think so. And I think what Judge Motley is doing is that Fred Thompson's testimony in the grand jury, in his witness statement, in the disclosure that the government made, is that there is a face-to-face argument with four people standing sort of around in a circle.  And I think that's why Judge Motley focuses on the fact that Fred Thompson's sort of key inconsistent information there is that there's a face-to-face argument. And then he relates all the evidence that shows quite clearly that it was not a face-to-face argument, which is why Fred Thompson wouldn't have helped upheld the trial. And in fact,  I'm sorry, I think you were going to say something. No, go ahead.
speaker: bryanhan

text: Go ahead. Finish.
speaker: judgeblackburn

text: I mean, in fact, I think that Attorney Harn testifies at the post-trial hearing that part of the reason why they are going for a defense of make the government prove its case instead of put on our own witnesses is because if they had to put on witnesses and those witnesses are disproven or inconsistent with or not credited by the jury,  that the jury will hold it against the defendant in that instance. And it would be more likely that he would be convicted. So I think this is, sorry, go ahead.
speaker: bryanhan

text: No, no, no. I was waiting for you to finish. I had a question on a slightly different tactic about this whole Brady question. Sure.  You know, the appellant's brief asserts that the government should have disclosed the identity of this witness, not just that there was this witness. And I'm not aware of any cases that require the government to do that. Are you? I am not aware of any cases that explicitly talk about the identity of the witness being disclosed.
speaker: judgeblackburn

text: And I do think that this is what often happens is that the government discloses the substance of what a witness testifies to, and then defense counsel follows up and says, we need to know who this is. And whether the government turns over the information or sets up a meeting between defense counsel and the witness to allow them access to that witness, that gets handled in pretrial litigation.
speaker: bryanhan

text: Council, um, Mr. Thompson comes to the government's knowledge, um, because he, how does he come to the government's attention?
speaker: judgeeasterly

text: Uh, he's a witness on scene. I'm not exactly sure. I'm not sure that it's.  Precisely in the record exactly how he comes to their attention. I know that he is the information that he gives part of it at least is in the arrest warrant for Miko Carraway, which is disclosed to Defense Council on April 8 I believe 2011
speaker: bryanhan

text: Right, and so presumably he is interviewed, it's in some sort of police notes or report or something, right? That's correct. And so even though the chief notes that we've not specifically discussed disclosing identity, certainly we've talked about in our cases, the obligation of the government to disclose the original Brady material as opposed to summaries of that information, right? And we have said in our cases,  the government really needs to turn over the original materials unless they can show that there's a reason that they need to summarize that and that they summarize at their peril. So I would think that the identity of the person providing the Brady information is a key fact that the government would need to be cautious about omitting.
speaker: judgeeasterly

text: And I think that's a good point, Your Honor. I think that  you know, the government balances this against, you know, concerns about witness safety and all those sorts of things in these kinds of cases. I think that if the, you know, even if the court thinks again that  Fred Thompson's identity should have been disclosed, that appellant's counsel should have asked about it, and that they should have interviewed him. I do think, again, Judge Motley fines and the weight of the evidence is against this face-to-face argument. And again, Fred Thompson also testifies that it happens in the parking lot, where we know from where the decedent's body is found, the pictures of where the decedent's body is found,  that that's not where the shooting happens because he's lying face down in the street near the sidewalk.
speaker: bryanhan

text: Were there security concerns or confidentiality concerns that were particular to Fred Thompson that would have, in the government's view, prevented them from disclosing his identity here? Or is it just sort of they didn't ask so we didn't say more?
speaker: judgeblackburn

text: If there are any particular security concerns, they're not in the record, Your Honor. And so, you know, we're sort of left with this, you know, just that the information was disclosed, they didn't ask, we didn't tell them.
speaker: bryanhan

text: Well, does that, and I guess that brings us back to the, why wasn't that ineffective assistance of counsel? And I guess your response is that Thompson's testimony would not have been that helpful as the appellant.
speaker: judgeblackburn

text: That's correct, Your Honor. Based on the information that they have, both from appellant and from the other evidence, that information wouldn't have been fruitful.
speaker: bryanhan

text: I wanted to ask a quick question in your remaining time. We didn't really touch on this during appellant's argument a moment ago. But was there, the government didn't respond to the concerns that appellant had about his attorney's failure to communicate with him.  appropriately and we didn't spend much time talking about that. Does the government have a position on that point?
speaker: judgeblackburn

text: Yeah, I think the reason why there hasn't been that much time spent on that is because there's no impact that appellant really claims from this failure to communicate other than, you know, the failure to investigate these witnesses that he supposedly told his attorney about. So absent any kind of prejudice and absent any actual impact on the case, I think that  even if there was some failure to communicate, and this wasn't really gone into at the post-trial hearing either, even if there was, that's not the basis of an effective assistance of counsel claim. And if there are no further questions, I'd ask the court to affirm the judgment of the Superior Court.
speaker: bryanhan

text: All right. Thank you, counsel. Ms. Milton, you have a couple of minutes of rebuttal time available.
speaker: judgeblackburn

text: Thank you, Chief Judge. So I just wanted to address some of the questions that you asked, Attorney Hahn. Mr. Frederick Thompson came about because he, I think he knew property manager, Shanetta Sapp, and he directly reached out to the police to tell them what he saw. If there was such an issue with credibility and what was going on and what he would testify to, I just wonder why the government would have asked for a grand jury testimony from him.  And, and furthermore, I'm attorney horn when he joins the defense team says he's disappointed with the state of the affairs he's disappointed that there wasn't more investigation.  If he had joined earlier, he would have investigated more. So I think that at least to the extent that there was a claim that there was a failure to investigate, even co-counsel agreed with Mr. Walker, who agreed that there was an insufficient investigation. And that really goes to the heart of our Sixth Amendment right to counsel because an early investigation could have helped attorneys decide how to dispose of the case.
speaker: monicamilton

text: Well, but I think that there's more to the test. And if you could go a little further, it's not under COSEO and our other cases. If there was an insufficient investigation, insufficient in and of itself is not enough unless you can show prejudice. And the fact that one attorney might have done more investigation than another attorney does not necessarily lead to the conclusion that  the investigation was insufficient to warrant ineffective assistance of counsel. So if you could just maybe say a little bit more about why, number one, Judge Attorney Harn's view that the investigation didn't go as far as he would have perhaps taken it, would lead us to the conclusion that there was ineffective assistance of counsel by Mr. Lewis.
speaker: judgeblackburn

text: Well, that goes to the fact that they didn't put on any defense.  evidence. So the government's case went unchallenged. And it went unchallenged in the face of there being disinterested witnesses out there. And so that produces, if you look at the cumulative effect of failing to investigate, failing to follow up with the witnesses,  you fail to present a defense. And you fail to present a defense that would have countered the government's case. That goes to the heart of the adversarial nature of our criminal justice system. The untested government's case, really, you have to question the reliability of the result. And that's what Strickland, the purpose of Strickland is. And so I think my time is up. So I just ask that this court  reverse the convictions of Mr. Walker because of his ineffective assistance of counsel claims and with respect to his Innocence Protection Act. Thank you.
speaker: monicamilton

text: Before you go, counsel, let me ask you this question. To play out the scenario, suppose we thought that the failure to investigate Mr. Thompson was a deficiency in representation by counsel.  And we thought that there's some possibility or something approaching a reasonable probability that there might have been a different outcome had there been an investigation and we were to order a new trial. I'm just trying to play out what would happen in the future. So let's say there were a new trial. Mr. Thompson  at least to date, cannot be found. And there are a lot of other witnesses who gave testimony about an altercation and the inconsistencies in their testimony were exposed. One of the witnesses even conceded that he didn't hear an argument. Some didn't hear arguments, et cetera, et cetera.  How would this case go forward on the theory that that you're thinking that the defense would have been able to develop with Mr Thompson's testimony because there is still the plea colloquy with Mr Caraway.  The government still has that. There was still the testimony of the other witnesses involved. How would that play out? I mean, it just seems that in the current setting, it's not clear how the cumulative evidence would have come out in a different way. Do you see it differently? I do.
speaker: judgethompson

text: First, because there were no eyewitnesses.  to the shooting. So this would become a credibility issue. We know at least with regard to the government's principal witness, Ms. House, that one, she was impeached. And secondly, the jury at least didn't believe her statements about Mr. Walker's possession of the gun because he was acquitted on the possession charge. So this would come down to credibility.  This disinterested witness testifying to what he saw, that there was an argument, that this was a spontaneous shooting as opposed to all of these other factors. Mr. Carraway seeking a beneficial sentence, plain guilty. Mr. Buchanan testifying, also another interested witness and was threatened by the government with prosecution. There was only one witness,  that did not have a stake in the outcome of the case. And so I think that does bear heavily on whether or not this case would have turned out differently because the government's witnesses, virtually all of them, had a stake in the outcome of the case.
speaker: monicamilton

text: All right. Thank you. I'd like to thank both counsel for your briefs and arguments today and this case is taken under advisement. Thank you.

text: Thank you, Mr. Jankowski.
speaker: judgeblackburn

text: Today, we're asking the court to
speaker: Unknown

text: Mr. Jankowski, I apologize, but it appears that your video and audio are freezing a little bit. So we're having- For four reasons, injury, coercion, issues in this oral argument.
speaker: judgeblackburn

text: Resolve this problem by having two detectives narrate and opine about otherwise- Mr. Jankowski, I apologize for interrupting you.

text: We missed the first few comments that you made because your video froze briefly.  Would you mind just repeating or briefly starting from the beginning, and we'll be happy to give you additional time, but your video froze for a minute, so we couldn't hear you.
speaker: judgeblackburn

text: We're asking the court to reverse Mr. Callaham's conviction for unarmed robbery for four reasons. I would like to rest on my brief on two of the issues and address in this argument only the lay opinion issue and the jury coercion issue.  Your Honor, because it did not have anyone, any witness, any eyewitness to say that a robbery occurred, the government had a problem. It couldn't prove that the robbery occurred. It attempted to resolve this problem by having two detectives narrate and opine about an otherwise ambiguous store surveillance video.  Your Honors, there's no firmer principle in the common law than that a witness must have personal knowledge of the facts about which he or she testifies. It is embodied in Federal Rule of Evidence 602, which has been adopted by this Court in Smith versus United States.
speaker: Unknown

text: Mr. Jankowski, could I interrupt you briefly again, this time with a question. Your confrontation argument  as I understand it, and correct me if I'm wrong, is that because the original, I guess, video sourced from, I think it was seven or several, at least, video cameras, creating hours of footage wasn't all played in full. Rather, there was a compilation video created to sort of parse down the amount of time  that the jurors and the court needed to take to review the video. You're saying that was a violation of the Confrontation Clause, even though the full sources from which the compilation was made was made available in discovery as I understand it.
speaker: judgeblackburn

text: The argument, the Confrontation Clause argument is that the store surveillance video itself was not introduced into evidence. What the government did was it took  Parts of that video and parts of the closed circuit television video that was a Metropolitan Police Department video that was taken from outside the store, they cobbled them both together to create an exhibit for use at trial. Why is that different from a summary of other documents and evidence that we typically allow to be admitted, particularly where the underlying source material was made available through discovery?  So this is not really a summary. It doesn't summarize the videos. It just takes certain parts of the video. And that's what my argument is on the confrontation clause. I would like to move on to my rule 701A if there's no further questions from. Well, the confrontation clause argument, I guess, is there something missing?

text: We don't know. And again, it's under Justice Scalia's opinion in Crawford v. Roberts, Crawford v. Washington, which ruled Ohio v. Roberts, it's not the accuracy of the exhibit that is the test. It is the method of determining the accuracy of the exhibit.  And that is by confrontation. So we don't really know how accurate this is, how accurate the compilation is, because the person who made the compilation did not testify in court. That's the issue. The issue is not per se the accuracy of it or the reliability of it.  not since Ohio versus Roberts was overruled, it's the method that is constitutionally required. As Justice Scalia said, it is the method which the Constitution requires and that method is cross-examination of the creator of the exhibit.

text: And I wanted to ask you briefly about your argument regarding how the polling of the jury took place and  the fact that the trial judge gave the Winters and Crowder instructions in the specific order that they were given. We do have cases saying that giving the Winters instruction after a jury poll is conducted could be considered coercive to the jury. But I'm not familiar with any cases where we felt that giving the Crowder instruction  following a jury poll is inherently coercive. I mean, I think we generally think of the Crowder instruction as perhaps not as strong or forceful as a Winters instruction. Do you have any cases to the contrary? And if not, why do you think the polling was coercive here, particularly since they only got to jury number two and then the trial judge stopped the polling of the jury?
speaker: judgeblackburn

text: I don't have any cases, and I'm fairly confident there are none. However, that certainly makes me feel a lot better. I was kind of worried about that. All right. Well, no, but here's why I think it is coercive, because a couple of reasons. Number one, the winner's instruction is the high water mark.  All right. So that, you know, giving the second anti-deadlock charge after the jury is told once, you know, we really would like to reach a verdict there. And they came out and incorrectly notified the court that they had reached a unanimous verdict. That was incorrect. They had not reached a unanimous verdict.  and then the court gives them another instruction, and in all probability, it was one juror. I mean, we don't know that for sure, but generally speaking, I've never sat on a jury, but if there is one holdout, I think just the dynamic, maybe there's one juror who just has a second thought when the poll is given, or maybe didn't articulate that juror's dissent clearly enough,  and the poor person thought they had a verdict. So you could see where, or maybe the juror just changed their mind when they walked in the courtroom or whatever. A poll breakdown suggests that there is only one, because if there's more than one, the probability that one juror didn't articulate their dissent clearly enough thereby  suggesting to the foreperson that they reached the unanimous verdict when they had not, the probability of those kinds of things happening is diminished. And I guess it's probably diminished by an exponential factor.  So I think that in all probabilities, one juror, and then the judge is instructed. Of course, this juror- But I'm not sure that there's a basis to assume that.
speaker: Unknown

text: I mean, if a juror poll was conducted and 12 or 14 jurors or 10 of 12 jurors are polled and you find that there's one, then it's more likely, I think,  that you can make that assumption. But we have cases that have held it where you're so early in the polling and you stop, which is what our cases instruct the courts to do, that you can't really make any speculation like that. And I don't think our case law supports that. The factors that we're supposed to look at are other types of coercive  actions that might have been taken. And I don't see those here. In fact, I see that the trial judge took steps to avoid those things. Yeah, the trial judge did end the poll right there.

text: Sure, Your Honor. Thank you. What we have are, we don't have the creation of a new video. I would just say that maybe that's not a fair characterization. We have 15  clips from 11 different cameras that are played one after another. And no one suggests that these clips could not have been played serially one after another and labeled as governance exhibits one through 15. They were just played one after another. It's not like we did a Hollywood video with theme music and cuts and lighting changes. This was just- The jury might've liked that better actually, but.
speaker: davidsaybolt

text: Of course they would.
speaker: judgeblackburn

text: But it is no different than if 15 still photographs or 15 clips or 15 autopsy photos, the selection of photos is not in and of itself a testimonial statement. Now, you asked me about case law. This court has the Bryant case where three surveillance videos were put together to be played and they were at the same time.  which is different. We have them here one after the other. And so the assertion was, well, the assertion of synchronicity was in itself a statement. And the court said, found no plain error there because the videos were authenticated. And there was a witness who said, didn't testify about the videos, but testified to the way the events  proceeded. So we don't have, an appellant has never articulated any way in which this compilation somehow represents a statement by anybody. The second case I would call court's attention to is the Cloutier case out of the 11th circuit. It was a subject of a 28k letter filed yesterday, where the court said the selection of government exhibits doesn't constitute a statement within the meaning of the confrontation clause.  And so that's our reasoning. We also know, I mean, you're a former trial judge, Your Honor, you know government defense. We select exhibits all the time. Those decisions that we make about this presentation of evidence are not statements. We're trying to tell a story. We're trying to convince the jury of a narrative, and we're asking them to draw inferences from the evidence, but we aren't making statements ourselves. We are simply presenting the evidence.  And so whether it's a crime scene diagram, or the selection of crime scene photographs, or the selection of autopsy photographs, or a clip from a video, we're not making statements. We're simply selecting what we think is the most relevant evidence. But our selection of what we think is relevant, again, isn't a statement as to relevance. We're just asking the jury to draw an inference. And it's tested by the adversarial process, which is why the court doesn't need to be concerned about  fairness or misleading because we all have the same evidence at trial and to the extent the defense thinks that something's misleading well they have the rule of completeness and the prosecutor is going to look silly if we leave out a photo that says something important or a clip in this case that says something important about the robbery.  So, can I ask a quick question though separate from confrontation, there is the issue of authentication.

text: And I find the statement and Brian kind of confusing because I'm not quite sure that I understand what authentication has to do with.  with the confrontation clause, right? The government is an advocate making its case for the people saying, we think this crime happened and that this person is responsible and should be held to account, right? That's their statement. Why is the detective allowed to tell the jury what they see on the video?

text: He's not. Well, this  First of all, it's an open question in this jurisdiction whether he would be considered a recipient witness. We know that a witness watching a live surveillance video can testify about what he saw. That was the Holmes case. And the courts are split outside this jurisdiction about narrating a video. What could possibly be your argument?
speaker: davidsaybolt

text: I'm sorry. Okay, so I mean that's I just if you want to Whether or not he could be a percipient witness what could possibly be your argument that he's a percipient witness. He's not there He's not watching it in real time He is in the exact same shoes as the jury watching this after the fact and and the trial court says this right she says I  This is the jury's decision. This is for the jury to decide and and you shouldn't be telling the jury what they see. This is their call. That's why I think she even says something to the effect of that's why we're here.
speaker: judgeeasterly

text: it's the video speaks for itself but detective Olzak's personal knowledge and the basis for his testimony comes in a couple discrete areas which you've already touched on Hunter. First of all he's familiar with the store and the layout of the street so he's pointing out you know the two different streets because the car is on one street the two men get out then the car comes around the street and then the two men come out of the store and take a right hand turn and get in the car  He's familiar with the cameras, he's familiar with the camera angles, and he's familiar with the course of their investigation. So when he talks about, well, you can see the appellant wearing this particular clothing, these particular shoes, and these particular torn jeans, and there's what over here, what looks like an assault rifle, that's why we seized at the execution of the search warrant at the appellant's girlfriend's house, those same clothes and this paintball box. So was any of that in dispute?
speaker: davidsaybolt

text: I mean, I can understand in a case where the question is, why is the police investigation going in the direction that it is that you could then introduce that kind of evidence, perhaps, but none of that is an issue here. Right. And what is at issue is, was there a robbery?  And he is telling the jury, look, you see him confront, you see them flee, you see he has a gun, you see they look scared, right? He is testifying to the jury on the precise matters that are in dispute and seems to have nothing, is saying nothing to anything that is not in dispute vis-a-vis the nature of the government's investigation or what investigative steps they took. Nobody's talking about that.
speaker: judgeeasterly

text: I'm not sure that I'm on the same page with you about what he said. You wanted to drill down on this.  He did say at one point fleeing and the judge struck that as an opinion that he could not offer about whether people were fleeing the two men on the street. I do not recall any testimony about his saying anybody looks scared. Mr. Jankowski and his brief at 39 to 40 talks about what he complains about Olzak saying. And each of these things we tried to say are he's calling the jury's attention.
speaker: davidsaybolt

text: How about you see the object that he's holding in his right hand? I do. And what does that appear to be as part of your investigation? An assault weapon. Why is that relevant to part of his investigation? I mean, that is, you know, did these people show up in a store and rob someone at gunpoint? And that's the whole issue for the jury to decide.  I don't understand what relationship that has to the investigation that's in dispute, right? No one is disputing that the government thought he had a gun. The question is whether or not, in fact, he did have a gun and whether or not the putative complainant was confronted with a gun and gave up property in response to being so confronted.
speaker: judgeeasterly

text: I understand your argument, Your Honor. I just would submit that I see it a little differently because it is relevant to the investigation in several ways. It's relevant to why they treated it as a robbery, and it's relevant to why they sent a search warrant. And he's describing what happened in the investigation. And whether or not it is in dispute, we do have, as Old Chief talks about, an obligation and a duty to present to the jury  the narrative of what happened. And we have a very high burden to prove that to the jury. And so when Detective Volpe testifies about why he went out and spoke to David Garvin on the street and why he asked some questions about what happened the night before, this explains that. When Detective Olzak talks about the clothes that he was wearing and what appeared to be an assault weapon, he's not opining about  it's an assault weapon. And ladies and gentlemen, you should believe it's an assault weapon. What he's saying is it looked like an assault weapon, which is why we investigated the robbery and why we recovered the paintball box from the execution of the search warrant. And the other things that he's doing, your honor, I would submit, he's essentially saying what we do all the time in court, here's a video, here's a photograph draw ladies and gentlemen, drawing your attention to,  what's going on here in the surveillance video, drawing your attention here to this, drawing your attention to that. We're making a record for the court of appeals and we're directing the jury's attention to a certain thing that's taking place in the evidence. But the court was clear and Detective Olzak was clear that it was the jury's province to interpret what they saw. He was just pointing out, directing their attention to certain aspects of what was relevant to the investigation.  All right, thank you.
speaker: davidsaybolt

text: Mr. Sable, we've gone a bit over time here. Unless there are any other comments or questions from my colleagues, is there a final statement that you'd like to make?
speaker: judgeblackburn

text: Could the government just give us its view of the jury coercion response to the defense's jury coercion argument?
speaker: judgeeasterly

text: Thank you, Your Honor. This court hasn't addressed whole breakdown after one scenario, but what this court has said numerous times is that the most effective thing the court can do to alleviate the potential for jury coercion is to give the full Crowder instruction, which contains, as you know, the language to any dissenters, do not surrender your honest convictions, which contains the language to a potential majority  reevaluate your positions. And the court did that. And we know that this scenario was less coercive, less potential for coercion than other scenarios where this court has said that Crowder was more than sufficient to alleviate the potential. I just have one question about that.
speaker: davidsaybolt

text: I mean, I'm hard pressed to say that this is less coercive, right? Because usually we have a jury, a poll breakdown, and then the Crowder instruction.  But here we have repeated questions from the jury that indicate that there have reasonable doubt. You have to impasse notes, resulting in a winter's instruction which is the high watermark.  And then it actually seems like the winners instruction that the concerns that we have about giving the winners instruction come to fruition because then we do have a jury that issues a verdict that is not in fact a verdict. Right.  And the poll breaks down, and then we give the crowd of instruction and I am just curious like it seems like the government just wants to focus on the poll breakdown followed by the crowder instruction but don't we have to look at the totality of the circumstances and the particular facts of this case which I think really give one pause.
speaker: judgeeasterly

text: Yes, obviously we need to look at the totality. You're correct, Your Honor. And so the jury starts deliberating on the afternoon, and they come back with two notes about, do you need a complainant? Is it a robbery without a complainant? Does a complainant have to complain? They come in the next day, and they announce that they have a verdict. And the court takes the verdict around lunchtime. Well, they have a few more notes before that, right?  I don't recall that. And I don't think there's the two notes in the afternoon that say, do you need a complainant? One is from the jury court person. The second one is from the court person. And the court responds to that. Then at lunchtime the next day, so they've been deliberating for less than five hours, they come back with a verdict, whole breakdown on the second. I'm sorry.

text: I think you've got the time wrong.  they come back and say, we're hung.
speaker: judgeeasterly

text: I'm sorry, you're right. Thank you, Your Honor.

text: Then they come back the next day, midday, and say they're hung.
speaker: davidsaybolt

text: Then they come back again and say, we're still hung. Then at some point, they get the very temperate instruction. Then they ask to see the stipulations of the undisputed facts.  Then they get the winners instruction, then actually the foreman sends a note that nobody knows about saying I'm not feeling well I'm not sure I'm going to be able to come back to work tomorrow, which seems to add to the course of nature. Right.  Right. You know, it's just, it's, it's a lot going on and they end up deliberating for as long as they heard evidence for, it's not a long trial. And really it all comes down to the videotape. And yet, they cannot make a decision.
speaker: judgeeasterly

text: They deliberate for a little over a day, Your Honor. The court made specific findings that the court did not know the split, that there was no impasse, that they were not deadlocked, but that the parties just wanted to go home by the end of the day. And that's when she gave the full Crowder instruction the next morning. I would submit to you that this was less coercive in a situation like Coley, for example.  And in Coley, we know that the dissenting juror sent several notes, and from the nature of the note, the court found, this court found, that the dissenter was identified, the dissenter was isolated and perceived herself as isolated, and the court gave only the first  The paragraph of the crowd instruction this and this, this court said, if you've given the full Crowder instruction that would have alleviated the potential for coercion, but the court didn't do that. And that was the case where the dissenter was identified and isolated and here that's simply not the case.  because of the earliness of the poll breakdown and because of specific findings made by Judge Knowles. Those are the kinds of facts that would give this court confidence that the jury was not unduly coerced. To find otherwise, Your Honor, this court would essentially be finding that anytime there's a poll breakdown after a winter's instruction, the court must declare a mistrial because the other factors here were all pointing in the direction of less coercion and not more.
speaker: davidsaybolt

text: All right, thank you council. Are there any final closing remarks you'd like to make?
speaker: judgeblackburn

text: I would simply say on the non-jury related issues, thank you that we had a lot of evidence. The video was the most important part, but we also had the still photographs which captured the key moments from the video that were not contested. We had the recovery of the matching clothing and the paintball box from the search warrant. And also we had the defendant's statements in the jail call that he was on the scene. So on the strength of all that evidence, we would submit that any error would have been harmless.  Thank you, and we'd ask that the judgment is superior court.
speaker: davidsaybolt

text: All right, thank you. Mr. Jankowski, you reserve two minutes for rebuttal.
speaker: judgeblackburn

text: Yeah, a couple of things. First of all, on the jury coercion issue, the way in which the jury returned the verdict is evidence of coercion. The original verdict that the foreperson, that turned out to be not a verdict,  The original verdict was guilty of armed robbery, right? The juror number two dissented on that. They came back and they were told again that it's, you know, we're trying to reach verdict here, okay? And then they come back with a verdict of unarmed robbery, which was irrational. Because if there was a robbery here,  the force or the threat of force would have been the use of the gun. Yet the jury found him un acquitted him of the armed element of the offense. So the juries are allowed to compromise to issue compromised verdicts. But the fact that it is a compromised verdict, just because that per se is allowable,  does not necessarily mean that the irrational verdict is not evidence of jury coercion. The jury was coerced in the verdict because there was at least one juror who disagreed with the armed robbery. They then went and delivered a verdict that was unarmed robbery, but the only  the only logical force was with the use of a gun. So that would have been, if the jury was uncoerced, they would have either found him not guilty of everything or guilty of the armed robbery. So I didn't say that as clearly as I'd like to, but the irrationality of the verdict  is evidence that the jury was compromised they they figured the judge wants us to the judge wants us to get a verdict so let's just do this uh another point um with respect to what mr sebold said about  Volpe's narration and Olsak's narration of the video was to show why they seized the clothes in the course of their investigation. Assuming arguendo that that's valid, because that's certainly not what the government said to the jury, but assuming arguendo that's valid, the prejudicial effect of that testimony  far outweighs any possible probative value. The probative value of that testimony is minimal, just about non-existent, but it is highly prejudicial because the witness is saying not only that a robbery occurred, but that these different facts that I'm seeing on the video, those facts constitute a robbery. It wasn't just his opinion that a robbery occurred,  It is, you know, these people come up, one of them's got a gun, and then they talk, and then there's a dropping of the bag, and then they picked up the bag, and then they ran out of the store. All those things, even without opining that that's a robbery, those things that the detective said constitute a robbery. So that's really the prejudice. It's not just them saying, oh, that's a robbery, and then the jury is told it's up for them to determine if it's a robbery.  So, and then with respect to what the government says about it not being a statement, it is a statement. It's a statement that a robbery occurred. If there was no statement that a robbery occurred in this case, the government doesn't survive a judgment of acquittal. So unless there's any further questions, I will submit on what I have already said.
speaker: Unknown

text: All right, thank you. I'd like to thank both counsel for your briefs and your arguments today. And this matter will be taken under advisement. Thank you.
